thread.title: Fan feared he would become infamous if Moustakas home run overtu
thread.title_full: Fan feared he would become infamous if Moustakas home run overtu - KCTV5

author: DeAnn Smith, Digital Content Manager
title: Fan feared he would become infamous if Moustakas home run overtu
text:
KANSAS CITY, MO (KCTV) - When Caleb Humphreys, 19, of Blue Springs took his seat in the outfield at Kauffman Stadium Friday night, he had no idea he was going to make national television.
And then in the second inning he feared he would become as infamous as Steve Bartman who many think cost the Cubs Game 6 of the NLCS in 2003. Humphreys was sitting in the right-field seating area at the K when he reached out and caught Mike Moustakas' homer.
The Blue Jays challenged the home run call, saying Humphreys reached into the field of play and interfered. Humphreys was sitting directly behind a railing that separates the seating area from the wall. According to stadium rules, a ball that hits the railing is a home run.
But once the umpires upheld Mike Moustakas' second-inning home run, Humphreys was feeling pretty good.
He told interviewers that he didn't reach over the wall to snatch the ball.
"I got really worried it was going to be taken away," he said about the umpire review. "I feared they were going to lose by one and I was going to be the kid who took it away."
But the umps didn't take it away and the home run stood.
"I'm on top of the world," the former Blue Springs baseball said. "I never expected to have this experience."
He said he planned to keep the ball for a long time unless Moustakas wants it back, saying he would gladly return it to the Royals third baseman.
"I'm definitely glad it happened," Humphreys said.
